reviews.reviewText:
A Hidden Gem in Hyderabad!

I recently visited the Nizam's Museum in Hyderabad, and I was blown away by the sheer grandeur and history that this place embodies. The museum is located within the Purani Haveli, which was the official residence of the Nizam of Hyderabad.

A Treasure Trove of History
The museum showcases an impressive collection of artifacts, including jewelry, furniture, and personal belongings of the Nizam and his family. The exhibits are meticulously maintained and provide a fascinating glimpse into the lives of the royalty.

Must-Visit Attractions
Some of the highlights of the museum include:

1. The Golden Throne Room: A stunning room filled with gold and silver artifacts, including a magnificent golden throne.
2. The Jewelry Collection: A dazzling display of precious stones and jewelry, including the famous Jacob Diamond.

Tips and Insights
- The museum is open from 10 am to 5 pm, and the entry fee is very reasonable.
- Guided tours are available, but you can also explore the museum on your own.
- Photography is allowed, but be respectful of the artifacts and exhibits.

Totally Not Worth It üò†üò°

Overpriced and super disappointing.
‚Çπ125 per person and ‚Çπ 150 for photography in a small-ass museum? Seriously? ü§¨
The place is tiny, boring, and staff were rude too.
Total waste of money. Don‚Äôt bother going.
The review should have been in negative.
üëéüëé
Your better off skipping this one and spending time at Chowmahalla Palace or Salar Jung Museum instead.
Save your time and money ‚Äî go literally anywhere else.
I will some photos, use those if you want and save time and money.
What A waste üòîüòîüòî

I gave this museum five stars only because I was lucky enough to get a one on one with one of the staff. The tour was unexpected but the staff saw that I was very interested in the articles being exhibited so they reached out and asked me if I would like a tour and of course I agreed. The museum was small and was in need of some TLC but it had some very interesting objects. What interested me the most we‚Äôre all the gifts that the local ruler received from both his subjectsÔøº and visiting dignitaries. They were so many objects made of both gold and silver I was truly amazed I had no idea that it such a small museum could hold so many precious objects.

The World‚Äôs Longest Wardrobe
@ H.E.H. The Nizam's Museum  was in my list while visiting Hydrabad .

The Nizams Museum  features Wardrobe of H.EH Nawab Mir Mahbub Ali Khan, the sixth  Nizam   of  Hyderabad (1869-1911) which is also the world's biggest or largest walk through wardrobe which is one of its kind, showcases some of the costumes worn in the city during the early 19th Century

The  wardrobe, is 176 ft. long and is made of the finest of  the Burma teak. It is constructed on two levels.

And the interesting fact said that The Nizam never repeated his clothes and once worn, his clothes were given away.

with a length of 240 feet (73.15 metres) was full of clothes, shoes and other accessories.

They took 124 almirahs ‚Äì sixty-four in one ground row and sixty on the second row atop the first to accommodate them.

In between the wardrobes in the lower row, there were some changing rooms.

The things exhibited  in the museum show that how luxurious was their life .

Nizam's Museum in Hyderabad is not worth visiting due to its ticket price and photography ticket both of them are too high for such small museum as compared to Salar Jung Museum (more exhibits low ticket price). Also there are no water and washroom facilities. The guard at the end gate of the wardrobe room also demanded a tip, which wasn't necessary and should not be given for the kind of service offered here.

I would say the conditions would happen for the museum especially the entrance it was quite confusing to understand where the entrance of the Museum is. I believe those details need to be mentioned by the Museum. Rest it is good and gives a proper old era vibes, although I would really enjoy it if it could have been bigger with more stuff. The ticket price seems to be a little pricey considering the stuff and the grandeur of the museum. Overall it was a good experience.

The museum showcases a collection of artifacts, gifts, and personal belongings of the Nizams, the former rulers of Hyderabad. The highlight of the museum is the gold tiffin box, which was stolen in 2018 along with other artifacts, but restored soon at its place. The place itself  gives you royal vibes about how opulent the erstwhile nizams were and how he was interested in keeping the gifts and artifacts safe during his regime. The impossible to believe fact is that the Nizam gave 2 tonnes of gold jewellery during the war time (see picture with the then prime minister of India Lalbahadur Shastri). Nizam VII was the modern architect of Hyderabad and built some magnificent Edifices.
It was actually really good with all the preserved things made with gold, silver, diamond, unique things to explore.

Upside Down Room: A quirky and fun photo spot, where the furniture and room settings are all inverted. Great for taking illusion-style pictures!

Trick Art Museum: Creative 3D art installations where you can pose with lifelike paintings that create cool visual effects in photos.

Mirror Maze: A fun and confusing experience where you try to find your way out of a maze of mirrors.

Haunted House: A mild scare attraction that‚Äôs more fun than frightening, good for a quick thrill.

Kid‚Äôs Play Area & Arcade Games: There are also sections with arcade-style games and small rides for kids.

Overall Experience:
It‚Äôs an entertaining half-day outing, especially if you want to enjoy snow in a tropical city. Clean, well-maintained, and worth visiting once, especially with children or for couples who want playful photo opportunities.

May 2025:

2. General upkeep of the place. Its dusty.

Sudha Car Museum is a fascinating blend of creativity, quirky humour, and engineering craftsmanship. Perfect for a short, fun outing‚Äîespecially with kids‚Äîit brings a smile with every turn. That said, if you expect pristine displays or modern visitor amenities, you might find some discomfort or rough edges.

We need to encourage the unique places like this.
I can understand the maintenance of this place and cars is difficult.
But overall the good place for quick and short fun ‚ò∫Ô∏è

Honestly, this has to be one of the weirdest and most frustrating museum visits ever. The ticket system itself feels like some kind of joke: ‚Çπ150 for adults and ‚Çπ120 for kids for a visit that barely lasts 10 minutes. On top of that, they shamelessly charge ‚Çπ100 extra just for clicking photos on your own mobile camera. No digital payment option, no proper billing, and to make it worse, they don‚Äôt even keep change to return your balance. You literally end up paying more because of their poor management.
As for what‚Äôs inside‚Äîsomeone with a very weird imagination has just taken random ideas, built cars shaped like fruits, vegetables, and household junk, slapped on an engine and tyres, and called it ‚Äúcreativity.‚Äù That‚Äôs it. Nothing more.
Parking? Space for maybe 10 cars max‚Äîagain, not thoughtful at all.
If you‚Äôre a car enthusiast or petrolhead, prepare to be utterly disappointed. There‚Äôs nothing about real cars, innovation, or automobile history here. At best, kids might find it amusing for a few minutes, but honestly, with these ridiculous ticket rates and pointless photo charges, it‚Äôs absolutely not worth it.
Overall, frustrating, overpriced, and a total waste of time. Not recommended to anyone.

reviews.reviewText:
Mrugavani National Park, located near Chilkur in Hyderabad, is a hidden gem for nature enthusiasts seeking a tranquil escape from the city. Spanning about 3.6 square kilometers, it‚Äôs an ideal spot to explore Telangana‚Äôs native flora and fauna. Here are my thoughts after visiting:

Pros:
1. Serene Atmosphere: The park offers a refreshing break with its lush greenery, making it a perfect spot for a day out. It‚Äôs less crowded compared to other parks in Hyderabad, which adds to its peaceful charm.
2. Wildlife Sightings: While exploring, you might encounter deer, peacocks, and a variety of birds. For bird watchers, it's a treat with several species like kingfishers and eagles being commonly spotted.
3. Guided Safari: The park offers a short safari ride that takes you deeper into the forest. It‚Äôs a fun experience for families, especially with kids who enjoy spotting animals in their natural habitat.
4. Watchtower and Nature Trails: The watchtower offers a panoramic view of the dense forest, while the nature trails are perfect for a light trek amidst nature. It‚Äôs a great place for photography enthusiasts.
5. Proximity to Chilkur Balaji Temple: If you're planning a full day trip, you can combine a visit to the famous Chilkur Balaji Temple, which is just a few minutes away.

Cons:
1. Limited Facilities: The park is relatively underdeveloped compared to other national parks. Facilities like restrooms and refreshment options are minimal, so it's advisable to carry your own snacks and water.
2. Short Safari Duration: The safari ride is quite brief, lasting only around 15-20 minutes. Those expecting a longer wildlife experience might be slightly disappointed.
3. Timing Restrictions: The park has specific visiting hours (typically 9 AM to 5 PM), so plan your visit accordingly to avoid being turned away.

Conclusion: Mrugavani National Park is a great destination for those who enjoy nature and wildlife in a serene, uncrowded setting. It may not have all the bells and whistles of larger national parks, but its natural beauty and tranquility make it worth a visit, especially if you're in Hyderabad looking for a short and peaceful getaway.

Resort located in a good place far from city. Not a huge place but fine for weekend getaway.

The service left a lot unfulfilled. The room allocation and cleanliness was not checked. Landline was not functioning, could not order room service. Water bottles were not provided.

Food was fine, not exceptional.

The safari ride is for minimum 10 people and it was not that comfortable.
Most of the time you will be able to see only deer as the name suggests it is murugavani park.
You can see deer from the outer road as well. Plan to walk a little bit to explore the area and search for the animals and birds.

Best place to visit with family.
So relaxing for adult and joyful environment for kid .
Must try there jungle safari

Very few things to see , deers can be seen easily and you can watch them very closely, kids can enjoy watching them. Apart from that there is nothing.
There is small safari which takes 20 mins, and minimum 10 people required for the safari to start.
Peace and calm in prime area huge forest area best for family out, kids enjoy with deers and peacocks birds

Peacocks and deers are there in the park and pleasant nature.But if you are going to take safari ticket,ensure that you buy a open cart safari ride for ride Rs.800 to start immediately otherwise if you by 80 or 70 rupees tickets you have to wait for the ride to fill up which is around 9 people in each ride.peacocks can be seen when you went on a safari ride.

Mrugavani National Park: Hyderabad‚Äôs Best-Kept Secret (Because It Should Stay That Way)

If you‚Äôve ever wondered what happens when a "national park" and a government-run disappointment have a lovechild, look no further than Mrugavani National Park‚ÄîHyderabad‚Äôs most efficiently forgettable attraction.

The "Wild" Experience (Or Lack Thereof)
For a mere ‚Çπ40, you gain entry to what can only be described as a slightly  ambitious municipal garden with an identity crisis. The entire "park" can be explored in less time than it takes to argue with an auto-rickshaw driver‚Äîmaking the journey here feel like an elaborate prank.

The much-touted "safari" (‚Çπ800) is an open-top joyride through‚Ä¶ well, mostly dirt and the occasional deer. The staff will helpfully inform you that the bus option (which would at least be cheaper) is mysteriously not running, leaving you no choice but the overpriced mobile oven they call a safari vehicle. If you‚Äôre expecting lions, tigers, or even a mildly interesting peacock, prepare for crushing disillusionment. For a far better wildlife experience, Nehru Zoo offers thrills at a fraction of the price‚Äîunless, of course, your idea of adventure is watching deer yawn in captivity.

The "Scenic" Viewpoint (Now with Bonus PDA!)
Eager for a breathtaking panorama of Hyderabad? Too bad. The viewpoint‚Äîwhich logically should be the park‚Äôs saving grace‚Äîis inexplicably blocked off. But fear not! With some determination ), you can reach the top‚Ä¶ only to be greeted by Hyderabad‚Äôs most amorous couples in what can only be described as nature‚Äôs own romance theatre. If you‚Äôve ever wanted to feel like an accidental extra in a low-budget romantic drama, this is your chance.

The "Information" Centre (A Study in Irony)
In a bold architectural statement, the park features an Information Centre‚Äîcomplete with both an entry and exit gate, a truly ambitious design for what is essentially a glorified storage closet. When I visited, it was closed (naturally), leaving me with more questions than answers. What secrets lie within? A single outdated brochure? A disinterested clerk? The world may never know.

Final Verdict: A Masterclass in Lowered Expectations
- Wildlife?More like mild-life.
- Romantic ambience? Only if you‚Äôre part of a couple (and even then, Nehru Zoo has better benches).
- Adventure? Unless you count avoiding unmaintained toilets, not really.

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ (1 star‚Äîbecause "zero" would imply effort was made.)
Who Should Visit?
- Couples looking for privacy.
- People who enjoy paying to see less than what a city zoo offers.
- Masochists who think *"government-run eco-tourism"* sounds like a good idea.

Pro Tip:Save your ‚Çπmoney, buy a plant for your balcony and name it "Mrugavani." It‚Äôll be far more exciting.

Happy (not) exploring!

Capital of a kingdom that flourished from the 14th to 16th century, with 87 semi-circular bastions.
Ornate, domed tombs from 18th century, built for Qutub Shahi dynasty rulers with landscaped gardens.
Village known for its traditional crafts & cultural shows, featuring a model village, museum & lake.
Bordered by a lake, this tree-filled park features gardens & grassy areas for recreation.

Iconic 16th-century mosque with 4 grand arches, 48m tall minarets and views over the Laad Bazaar.
Paths & benches on a landscaped green space with ancient trees & play equipment around a lake.
Imposing, hilltop Hindu temple built of white marble, with towers, shrines and interior carvings.
Former art collection of the Salar Jung family from around the world, now a museum.
A large Buddha monument rises atop a giant rock in the midst of this heart-shaped, urban lake.

Large city reservoir with park-like space popular for picnicking & viewing of sunrises & sunsets.
This 83-acre lake in Ranga Reddy district features fishing, boating, a floating fountain & more.
Large recreational lake framed by rocky shoreline with low-key lodging & picnicking options.
Sprawling, 20-acre seaside park with exercise fields, an olympic track, tennis courts & a gymnasium.
Natural park & picnic spot overlooking a lake with play equipment, paved footpaths & seating areas.
Large reservoir with grassy banks, popular for picnics & renowned for its sunset views.
Monolith of Gautama Buddha on its own island in  Hussain Sagar lake, which can be reached by boat.
Contemporary, terracotta-colored Hindu temple adorned with vibrant wall carvings of gods & animals.
This family-friendly indoor park filled with artificial snow has slides, games & play areas.
Quirky museum with a collection of cars designed by Sudhakar Yadav to look like everyday objects.
Expansive national park with a variety of plants & birds, including peacocks, plus paths for running.
Artifacts from the entirety of the city's history built by a former ruler to celebrate his family.
Largest green space in Hyderabad, featuring wildlife like blackbuck antelope & guided safari tours.
Small, modest park area offering a few walking trails & wildlife such as deer.

Quiet Gachibowli is a corporate district home to business parks with tech company offices, as well as campuses for the University of Hyderabad and other educational institutions. Lounge bars and upscale Indian and international restaurants cater to those who work in the area or live in nearby high-rise apartments. Gachibowli Stadium and GMC Balayogi Sports Complex host soccer, basketball, and other sports.

Ritzy Banjara Hills is an upscale dining and nightlife hub centered on Road Number 1, where smart bars and cafes, high-end Indian restaurants, and hotels with nightclubs sit alongside popular shopping malls like City Centre and GVK One. Other exclusive shops, with Indian designer wear, jewelry, and saris, are concentrated on Road Number 10. Peaceful Jalagam Vengalrao Park offers trails and a lake.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Hyderabad, a city where history and modernity intertwine, offers a plethora of stunning backdrops for photography enthusiasts. From the majestic Golconda Fort, perched high on a granite hill, to the intricate architecture of the iconic Charminar, every corner of this vibrant city tells a story. Whether you're capturing the serene beauty of Hussain Sagar Lake with its towering Buddha statue or the ornate details of the Chowmahalla Palace, Hyderabad is a treasure trove of picturesque spots waiting to be explored.

As you wander through the bustling streets and tranquil parks, you'll discover hidden gems like the Sudha Car Museum, where creativity meets automotive art, and the lush greenery of Sanjeevaiah Children's Park, perfect for a leisurely stroll. The blend of cultural heritage and contemporary charm makes Hyderabad a photographer's dream. So grab your camera and get ready to uncover the best photo spots this captivating city has to offer!
